docs.lead_paragraph: As Hillary Rodham Clinton tries to rebut the favorite attack line of Representative Rick A. Lazio, that she has never held public office and has no record for a Senate campaign, she and her husband and their staffs are aggressively trying to reverse the reclusive image that she projected after her failure on health care reform. Now Mrs. Clinton says that rather than retreating, as the White House maintained, she was in fact working hard behind the scenes proposing, writing and lobbying for certain legislation, budget appropriations and administration policies. Her record, she said, includes work on a major Clinton administration child-care initiative, a huge federal-state children's health insurance program, adoption and foster care bills and foreign aid appropriations for small loans overseas.

headline.main: In Shift, Mrs. Clinton Stresses Behind-the-Scenes Influence

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in effort to rebut Rick A Lazio's attack line that she has never held public office and has no record for a Senate campaign, is aggressively trying to reverse reclusive image that she projected after her failure on health care reform; now Clinton says that rather than retreating into more traditional First Lady role, as White House previously maintained, she was in fact working hard behind scenes proposing, writing and lobbying for legislation and administration policies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, through a group it created called American Family Voices, has joined the political advertising wars with a 30-second television spot titled ''Invest.'' The advertisement takes George W. Bush to task for several decisions he has made as governor of Texas and tries to link them to large contributions to him and the Republican Party from the insurance, nursing home and drug industries. The slickly produced advertisement does not urge viewers to vote against Mr. Bush or for Vice President Al Gore, but asks them to call Mr. Bush's office or visit the sponsoring group's Web site.

headline.main: A Union-Created Group Attacks Bush on Health Care Issues

docs.abstract: Description of television advertisement launched by American Family Voices, group created by American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, attacking Gov George W Bush on health care and campaign financing issues; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK BRONX: COCAINE SEIZED -- Federal agents yesterday announced the seizure of nearly 670 kilograms of cocaine in the Bronx on Saturday. They said that agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration and New York City police officers arrested three men and charged them with drug trafficking after searching a van and finding 50 kilograms of cocaine. The other 619 kilograms were discovered during a search of a nearby apartment. John Sullivan (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Turning to a second legal loophole after another was closed, one of the nation's largest unions, a leading supporter of Vice President Al Gore, has quietly created a group that this week is televising an advertisement harshly critical of Gov. George W. Bush. Neither the group's ad nor its Web site (www.checkforyourself.com) discloses its relationship with the union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, or Afscme.

headline.main: Finding Another Loophole, a New Secretive Group Springs Up

docs.abstract: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, leading supporter of Vice Pres Al Gore, has quietly created group American Family Voices, which is televising advertisment harshly critical of Gov George W Bush; neither group's ad nor its Web site disloses its relationship with union; organization, created in July after Congress closed legal loophole known as Section 527, is chartered under Section 501(c)4, tax code provision that allows it to engage in political activity with minimal financial disclosure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna U.S. Healthcare will change its payment system for all its primary care doctors in Connecticut in an effort to improve relations with physicians in Connecticut, Aetna officials said yesterday. Aetna announced in May that for physicians with 100 or fewer Aetna clients, it would abandon the current program, which pays primary care physicians a fixed amount per patient each month, regardless of the time spent with a patient. The original announcement would have affected about 70 percent of Aetna's 1,800 network doctors in Connecticut.

headline.main: Metro Business; Aetna Is Changing System of Payments

docs.lead_paragraph: Schein Pharmaceutical Inc., a generic-drug maker, said today that New York, Florida, Nevada and other states had issued subpoenas seeking information on its drug-pricing practices. ''Schein has received notices or subpoenas from the attorneys general of various states, including Florida, Nevada and New York,'' the company said in its most recent quarterly Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline.main: Schein Subpoenaed by States on Pricing

docs.lead_paragraph: Talk about ugly. The performing artists and the visual artists are barely speaking to one another. Two mediation sessions have collapsed. Accusations have ricocheted off the peeling walls of the building where the artists pursue their muses. In the bathrooms and hallways, the graffiti reads: ''Corruption. Scandal. Violence.'' In the arts world, passions can run pretty deep. But passions have carved a Grand Canyon-size divide among warring factions of artists fighting for control of the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side. And the fight could end up in a death grip, with all the artists being kicked out of the castlelike building.

headline.main: Artist vs. Artist, Vision vs. Vision; 2 Groups Battle for Control of City-Owned Cultural Center

docs.abstract: Performing artists and visual artists battle over control of Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center on Lower East Side of Manhattan; both groups have decided to fight city's efforts to shut down center independently; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nassau County executive and other officials turned a blind eye while connected Republican businessmen concocted a health insurance deal that cost the county $40 million, an independent investigator said in a report released today. The county, in 1997, hired a Suffolk County company, Benefit Plan Administrators, to manage its new system of self-insurance. The plan was to save money by having the county pay its own health care costs for 26,000 employees and retirees. Benefit Plan Administrators guaranteed savings of millions of dollars.
docs.abstract: Milton Mollen, independence investigator, reports that Nassau County Exec Thomas S Gulotta and other officials turned blind eye while connected Republican businessmen concocted a health insurance deal that cost county $40 million; says hiring of Benefit Plan Administrators in 1997 to manage county's new system of self-insurance resulted in cost overruns, fiscal disarray and questions concerning consulting fees and commissions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a Democratic fund-raiser last month at the Upper West Side duplex apartment of the singer Paul Simon, Vice President Al Gore was introduced by Connecticut's senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman. After some preliminary remarks about the strength of the economy and the old ideas of Republicans, Mr. Gore began to bash big oil and big insurance companies, a staple nowadays of his stump speech.

headline.main: An Ally of Big Business Balances a Friend of the Earth

docs.abstract: Sen Joseph I Lieberman, Vice Pres Al Gore's running mate, is perceived as business-friendly Democrat on wide array of issues; his stands could help ticket in its fund-raising and in reassuring corporate leaders nervous about Gore's environmental views; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the announcement yesterday by Vice President Al Gore that he had named Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate, as recorded by The New York Times. Also speaking in an appearance at a Nashville war memorial were Mr. Gore's wife, Tipper, Senator Lieberman's wife, Hadassah, and Senator Lieberman.
